In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.

138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.

TUESDAY, JULY 30, 1907.

div.head: THE PROBLEM OF LOST CHAMPIONSHIPS.
div.p: “ Whither have gone the majority of our English championships ? Where are those proofs of prowess which it should be Eng land’s proud boast that she is able to retain I —a boast, alas ! she can no longer with fairness maintain. The cup of bitterness, for those who ever aver that in the world of sport England still stands first, must during the past few weeks have been full to overflowing, the culminating point being arrived at in the week that has just passed, when the foreigners triumphed in nearly everything tor which they competed, ” so bewails the “ Daily Telegraph. " ,
“ Briefly, a number of English championships may be located as follows :
Golf in France.
Tennis in America.
Lawn Tennis in Australasia and America. Sculling (professional) in Australia. Rowing in Belgium.
Yachting in America and Germany. Pole-jumping in Sweden.
Swimming in America and Australia.

Thus it is that the pupil has in many instances become more efficient than his master, and England, after imparting her knowledge to those abroad, is hoist with her own petard, and now has to stand quietly by whilst English championships one by one leave their native shores, some for the first time. To the mind at once recurs the question, “Are we deteriorating physically 1 "

A writer who signs himself “ Emeritus " frames the following indictment against our youth on the evidence of the last few weeks : “ What is the matter with our young men ? It is a question which is in everyone’s mouth, and which no one seems able to answer. ‘ Slackness,’ as a generic term for nerveless ness, want of tone, absence of ardour, of keenness, of‘go,’ has, I believe, been practically invented by our gilded youth—and they are the best examples of it themselves. What do they do with their time ? They do not study harder than they used to do—that much can assuredly be taken for granted. They have not become more serious, more thoughtful, more sedentary in their occupations. They do not cultivate the simple life. It would be useless to find in them brilliant examples of the Non-conformist eon science, either at its best or its worst They are supposed to be athletic, to have no other thoughts but for outdoor exercise or sport. It they are inclined to vaunt themselves on any-things, it is on the fact that they love an existence in the open air, and can do most thing with ease which involve the use of hands and legs. And the melancholy fact is that not even in their chosen pastimes are they beyond a fair second-class level. They are too slack to take pains. Most things are ‘above.’ Sceptical of things that move the world, sceptical of thought, sceptical of sentiment, sceptical of themselves. They have nof the energy to take in their own darling pursuits, in which, more and more every year, they are being beaten by ‘the foreigner.’

The “Pall Mall’’ discusses the same subject under the heading, “Are we Degenerate f’ and says: “On the whole it may well be doubted whether the British athlete, either amateur or professional, is a worse man than his father before him ; and for our part, we see no shame in being fairly beaten by men whom we only despised in the past because we never thought they would put us to the proof. To our mind it is neither very British nor very sportsmanlike to howl over our national degeneracy merely because other nations can hold their own against us in the sports which we ourselves have taught them."

div.head: LOCAL, AND GENERAL.
div.p: Arrests.
ý thefts, 22 misdemeanors and 52 minor ottences occurred in Cairo yesterday. Notice to Readers,
We regret that owing to the heavy pressure won our space we are compelled to hold over several items of minor importance until tomorrow's issue. British Consular Court.
Notice of appeal has been given by the waintiff in the case of Parker v. Hinshelwood and Company. The judgment was given in l'esterday's issue. Ivory
Vineteen tons Egyptian, and eight tons byssinian ivory, have arrived in London for the quarterly sales, which cominence July 23. The total arrivals amount to 53 tons. Quarantine.
Consequent to the recrudescence of bubonic vlague in Egypt, quarantine of five days"
ainst Egyptian ports has been declared by the Ottoman authorities to be passed in one of the lazarets of the Empire, and 10 days" quarantine is notified for Malta. Aotion against Nowspapers,

The libel action against the newspapers "Al Mokattam," "El Shark" and "El Watan" came on for hearing yesterday before the Ezbekieh Summary Court. On the representations of comsel for the defendants the further hearing was adjourned to the 7th proxo. Roughs in Cairo.

While driving in his carriage through the Darrassa quarter on Tuesday last, Dr. Mohamed Bey Fakkat was attacked by a gang of native roughs, without any provocation being given, and was so severely injured that he will require some 15 days medical treatment. The Vivante Mystery.

A Spaniard was arrested at Alexandria this morning on suspicion of having been concerner in the murder of Mr. Vivante. He bears a resemblance to the person who hired ar adjoining room. The staff of the hotel have been summoned to the Spanish consulate to confront this man. The arrested man has not been definitely identified, though he hears a great resemblance to the man who occupied the room near Vivante's and left the hote carly in the morning. Cattle Plague.

180 fatal cases of cattle plagne occurred throughout Egypt during the week ending 15th instant of which 5 were reported fron the province of Charkia, 51 from Beni-Souef 28 from the Fayoum, 13 from Ghizeh, 4 from Kalioubia, 66 from Assiout and 19 from the province of Minia. Pedlars at Khartoum. · Residents in the eastern part of Khartou complain of the presence of women pedlors ir that quarter, who have installed themselves on street corners, and have made themselves something of a nuisance to decent people. The attention of the local anthorities has beer called to this matter. It is suggested that smal shops or wooden stands might be built there and let to responsible persons who will sel such articles is there seems to be a demand for, and who will see to it that no canse fo similar complaints is furnished. Cotton at Cabbary.

The Egyptian State Railways Administra tion with a view to facilitating the goods worl at Gabbary station and in order to provid more accommodation for unloading all the in ward goods during the cotton season, ha: decided, after consultation with the Alex andria Produce Association, that during the four months, October 1st to January 31st each year, the withdrawal of cotton bales Gabbary on Sundays will be obligatory, thus making Sunday an ordinary day, on which demurrag will be collected in cases of delay.
Bubonic Plague.

Yesterılay's plagne bulletin reports 3 admissions to hospital at Alexandria, one of whom is i Greek sponge merchant of the Menshieh him, and the remaining two natives, one from Gabbary and the other from Mafrouza

Minet el Bassal). Two Europeans died in hospital, of whom one was Mme. Agulhon, widow of the late proprietor of the Hotel de la Poste, who, it will be remembered, also died from the plague. One new admission to hospital is reported from Port Said, and one recovery at Damanhoor.
Cairo Fires.

The fire which broke out at midday on Tuesday last, in Sharia Mohamed Ali near Darb el Nahabli, was extinguished shortly before 4 o'clock owing to the prompt attendance of four fire engines. Fortunately no lives were lost, but several families are now homeless and are dependant ipon the kindness and charity of their neighbours. Over L.E. 4,000 of damage was done to property, which was not covered by insurance. The conflagration is believed to have originated in a carpenter's shop, owing to the overturning of a spirit lamp at which he was heating some glue. The big outbreak in the Sharia Mohamed Aly on Tuesday quite eclipsed the three other smaller outbreaks, the larger of which was that in Khalifa Khatatbah (Citadel Quarter). Four rooms of the ground floor in a native house caught fire in the quarter mentioned owing to fire being communicated from a confectioner's oven. On the arrival of the brigade, immediately after the call, the fire had already'obtained a good hold, but owing to active efforts the Hames were suppressed and all danger averted within three quarters of an hour.

THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
CAIRO'S TROUBLES.
COTTON INTERESTS UNCONCERNED.

LONDON, Thursday. The number of firms of repute in Cairo, whose suspension of payment has just been announced here, has aroused fresh interest in the financial crisis at present raging in Egypt I have good grounds for believing that the commercial and financial difficulties that have thereby arisen with Manchester and London are likely to be tided over. It has been decided that the liquidation that will ensue will be conducted privately. The management of these liquidations will be entrusted to a trustee belonging to a well-known firm at Manchester.

Various estates of the firms concerned have been saved for the creditors. It is understood that the Banks and the trade creditors will act together. General satisfaction is felt at the policy that is to be pursued by the London and Manchester banks, which is considered very sensible.
The liabilities of the concerns compromised by these failures in no way concern the important cotton interests of Lancashire.
Regarding the failures reported in our issue of yesterday our Cairo correspondent writes :

The figures as stated by your contemporaries were not quite exact. As a matter of fact the assets in the case of all the houses involved considerably exceed the liabilities, in some instances as much as much as 150%. It has been very fairly demonstrated that a gradual liquidation is in the interest of all parties, and the principal ground for complaint and the cause of the critical state of affairs is due to shyness of banks in London, Manchester and other quarters, owing to the discredit thrown on the Egyptian market, by the existing state of affairs. From the quarter in which I obtained my information I gathered that there was not any question of insolvability of any of the firms in question, it being to the general interest to obviate this unhappy event. The holding of ready money by the conservative | action of several parties has brought the situation to a head and caused a regrettable situation which might have been avoided, had there not been somewhat of a rush for the realisation of Stocks and Shares, and as already mentioned

the stoppage of time drafts. The firms in ques. |tion were entirely unprepared for the heavy demand on their resources, brought about by the suppression of London and Manchester credits, and not having ready cash to meet their obligations, and in addition, a large amount of capital outstanding in various directions, they were naturally extremely hardly pressed, and their only recourse was to take the step which has been recorded in the Press. Remarks have been made in a paper, which it is needless to name, in regard to the AngloEgyptian Bank. It has been definitely asserted that the Anglo-Egyptian Bank is not involved to the extent of more than L.E. 20,000, and the reflections made in this connection prove to be imfomded. | It is regrettable to notice that owing to the | present crisis a very large number of employés have been dismissed from their employment, and in many cases without any consideration for having lost their positions without notice. In addition to this there has been a large influx of seekers after employment in this country, and the result is that the labour market is now overcharged, and, as remarked by one of our contemporaries, there is more possibility of a strike of the unemployed than of a financial crisis. At the same time it is worthy of note that in certain quarters there is a pretty firm opinion that the failures already recorded will very possibly be followed by others, and it seems evident that the desire should be distinctly manifested to re-establish the system of three months drafts in connection with commercial houses in their dealing with England. It is to be hoped that the | British Banks will in their turn come to the aid of the Egyptian banks in such a manner as to prevent the complete dislocation of Egyptian commercial relations with England, which would be extremely detrimental to the present and future interest of the country.
We are informed that the number of unemployed in Alexandria, consisting almost entirely of clerks, is no less thần 540. EI. E.G

LAUNCH OF THE “CAIRO."
A FASHIONABLE GATHERING:
(From OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT.)

Glasgow, July 11. Severe thunderstorms broke over the coun| try yesterday afternoon, and a watery sunset did not augur well for the following day. However, the gods proved kinder than was anticipated and the good steamship "Cairo" was successfully launched a few hours ago in | fine weather, although the temperature for the time of year was somewhat below normal..

The Countess of Cromer, who had kindly consented to perform the naming ceremony, arrived at the railway station this morning accompanied by her brother-in-law and sister, Sir Hugh and Lady Octavia Shaw-Stewart, where they were met by the Chairman and Directors of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company. Carriages were in waiting and the party at once drove to the Fairfield Ship| building and Engineering Co.'s Works, Govan, where a large and distinguished gathering had already assembled. Amongst others present were Major and Lady Victoria Villiers, Lord Armstrong, H.E. Boghos Pasha Nubar, Mr. and Mrs. G. T. Symons, Mr. and Mrs. Carton de Wiart, Mr. Alfred Curphey, Mr. Arthur Capel, Mr. George Armstrong, Monsieur Cadean, Admiral Sir Digby Morant, Colonel Paget Mosley, Mr. and Mrs. R. R. Bevis, Mr. Alexander Gracie, Mr. A W. Sampson, Mr. and Mrs. F. Formby Back, Mr. George Strachan, | Prof. Bjles, Mr. R. Whitehead, Mr. and Mrs.

H. C. Walrond, Monsieur l'Hermite, Captain Wilson-Barker, Mr. F. J. Debenham, Mr. P. C. Burton, Mr. and Mrs. W. C. Donaldson, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. Donaldson, Mr. J. J. Barrie, Mr. C. C. Barrie, Mr. A. F. Donaldson, Mr. Graham Findlay, Mr. J. P. Maclay, Mr. Robert Headrick, Dr. and Mrs. C. Burland, Mr. Frank Collinson (Architect), etc., etc. Everything now being ready for the launch of the second of the new liners, the visitors repaired to the raised dais, which had been erected under the bows of the "Cairo." In the centre of the dais a table had been placed, on which was fixed an electrical arrangement enabling the hydraulic machinery to be put in, motion, and the great liner to be released from her stays. Punctually at one o'clock, the hour fixed for the launching ceremony, Lady Cromer approached the table and, with a blow from a bright steel axe, set in motion the electrical machinery, and at the same time, in a clear voice, naming the huge steel mass in front of her "Cairo”, and bidding it "God Speed." Immediately the enormous hull began to glide, and slowly and gracefully took the water in a little under one minute, amid the ringing cheers from all present, the launch being accomplished without the slightest hitch.

The Company then repaired to the Model Room in the Fairfield Co's Works, where a most elegant luncheon had been provided by the Directors. The Chair was occupied by Mr. Alexander Gracie, the Managing Director of the Fairfield Company, Lady Cromer being seated on his right. After the toasts of His Majesty the King, The Queen, and the Royal Family, had been proposed by the Chairman, and loyally responded to, Mr. Gracie proposed success to the steamship “Cairo”, and prosperity to the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, to which Lord Armstrong, as Chairman of the Steamship Company, replied. He said it was | a great pleasure to him to express his great satisfaction at seeing the “Cairo”, the second of their great Egyptian Liners, so successfully take the water. Everyone must regret the absence of Lord Cromer, who had played so noble a part in the building up of modern Egypt, and the thanks of the Company were due to Lady Cromer for taking part that day in helping to build up the new Egyptian line, which, he felt sure, would be second to none in the Mediterranean, and would be the most rapid and comfortable means of transit between Europe and Egypt. These magnificient steamers had been built with the greatest care, and would not only be the largest and fastest boats in the Mediterranean, but would reduce the voyage by 1. days. Lord Armstrong pointed out the remarkable increase of visitors to Egypt, the numbers having doubled in the last five years, the total in 1906 being 107,000, not including 15,000 more who had disembarked at Suez.
His Excellency Boghos Pasha Nubar also retumed thanks on behalf of the Company. Speaking in most excellent English, he said :My Lords, Ladies & Gentlemen.
I hope you will allow me to appeal to your kind indulgence as my knowledge of

I hope you will allow me to appeal to our kind indulgence, as my knowledge of our language is, unfortunately for me, so mperfect, that I would never have dared co address you in English, if I had not been asked to do so.

It is in my capacity as an Egyptian memper of the Company's board that I have he honour of speaking to day. I shall, thereore, confine my remarks to bringing out he Egyptian point of view of our underaking.

In this connection I would recall a statement made by the late Khedive, Ismail Pasha, many years ago, in a speech which has remained familiar in Egypt. Alluding to che political importance already acquired by Egypt and to the high degree of civilisation co which she had attained, His Highness Cemarked: "My country no longer forms part of Africa, it is now-a-days part of Europe."

Thirty years håve nearly past since, and Che country has made constant progress durng this interval, and has greatly developed morally, so that to day, with even greater accuracy and truth, one can say that Egypt is no longer part of Africa, but part of Europe.
But, if this statement may be considered as exact, when you take into account the

progress made by our rich and fertile country, all those, who, like me, have to make the journey .yearly, must confess that the above statements must be taken figuratively, and that too prolonged crossings by sea separate is still from that Europe to which we have the legitimate ambition to belong.
It is in order to obviate this and to shorten materially the duration of the crossing, that The Egyptian Mail Steamship Coy. has been founded.

Now that our two immense steamers are afloat, it only remains to express the hope that they will answer the reasonable demands of the pnblic by giving them the rapidity of transit and the comfort.which they are justified in expecting
Under such circumstances there can be no doubt as to the success of our Company, which will bring Europe into more rapid communica|tion with such a rich and a prosperous country as Egypt.

People who are not acquainted with the real situation of Egypt may, perhaps, be astonished at hearing me allude to the prosper|ity of Egypt at the very moment when she is passing though a financial crisis, but, I think, the trne nature of the crisis is imperfectly understood in Europe, and as I have been asked to give my views on the subject, I will do it in a few words. In my opinion, it is solely due to the reckless speculation on the shares of the too numerous companies, which have been promoted lately and launched with disregard of common prudence and without | adequate necessity, and also to speculation on | the building land in the towns, the prices of which have been forced up to exaggerated values. A reaction was inevitable and took place, as might have been expected, suddenly.

But it would be a mistake to think that the crisis affects the whole country, and, I am glad to say, it has not, in any way, affected the chief source of the wealth of Egypt, which consists of the cultivable land, whose marvellous fertility is displayed in the production of all crops and especially of cotton. You find the best illustration of this in the fact that the prices of cultivable land are not only maintained, but have attained higher values than they ever reached before.

To revert to our ship and to the future for our enterprise, allow me to add, that the presence of the Countess of Cromer, as sponsor of the “Cairo" is a happy angury for success. Her name is too well known to require any eulogy on my part, save to express the hope, that her eminent and distinguished husband, whose absence I personally regret, shall shortly be restored to health and will resume the | active career, in which he has done so much | for his country and for Egypt.
In conclusion I would express the wish, that Lord and Lady Cromer will soon take a passage by the “Cairo” and pay us a long visit in Egypt.

Admiral Sir Digby Moran then proposed the health of Lady Cromer, and voiced the feelings of the Company present when sincerely regretting the absence of Lord Cromer, and the serious indisposition which had compelled him to refrain from taking part in any public | functions for the present.

Sir Hugh Stewart, Lady Cromer's brother in-law, returned thanks for her ladyship, and after the success of the Fairfield Co. had been proposed in felicitous terms by Major Villiers and replied to by Colonel Mosley, the guests separated. | Before leaving the luncheon room Admiral

Sir Digby Morant presented Lady Cromer with a beautiful silvered axe, the blade of which had been forged from a piece of the steel of which the "Cairo" had been built. This axe, with which the ceremony of launching had been performed, was inounted on a beautiful ivory handle with gold setting, and wil for ever remain as an interesting memento of the kind offices which she had undertaken to-day in naming the S.S. "Cairo.'
Several of the guests afterwards paid a visit to the “Heliopolis” which is fast approaching completion, and which it is hoped will be ready to commence running in November next
LORD CROMER
LORD CROMER

The Earl of Cromer's many friends in Egypt, writes a London correspondent, will regret to learn that his Lordship's health still prohibits him from receiving any but the most intimate friends. Lord and Lady Cromer are going
in a few days to Scotland, where his Lord-ship intends remaining for several months,
as absolute rest and immunity from excitement are considered essential by his medical advisers.

Lord and Lady Cromer have been on a visit to Sir Hugh and Lady Alice Shaw-Stewart at Ardgowan near Greenock. During the first part of their visit to Scotland they will be the guests of Mr Thomas Baring at Castle Leod, Rossshire, and will spend October at Nairn.

EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
THE DENSHAWI PRISONERS.
Mr. W. Redmond asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, in the House of Commons on Tuesday week how many of the Denishwai prisoners had been released.

Sir E. Grey (Foreign Secretary): The sen tences of imprisonment originally passed or two of the prisoners have now expired. I under stand that a petition to the Khedive praying for the release of the prisoners is being cir culated for signature in Egypt by the Nation alist paper “El Lewa.” I have no other in formation on the subject. | Mr. Redmond : Does not the right hon gentle man think that the time has come when these sentences might be revised ? | Sir E. Grey : I cannot give any further ans wer at the present moment.
Mr. Redmond : Then, on the proposed vote | to Lord Cromer I will call attention to thei continued imprisonment.
Mr. J. M. Robertson (L-Tyneside): Is i not a fact that an important petition has been presented to the Khedive recently with regard to the release of the prisoners ?
Sir E. Grey : I presume that is the petition to which I referred. My information was tha the paper "El Lewa” was getting up a petition

THE GRANT TO LORD CROMER. Mr. W. Redmond asked the Prime Minis ter on Thursday if there was any prece dent for the proposal to give a public gran of money to a civil servant who was already | entitled to a pension ; and whether, in the
event of such a proposal being made in re | ference to Lord Cromer, ample notice woul be given before any resolution was made i the House.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman : Yes, ther | have been cases varying in amount. accord ing to the circumstances. With regard to the second part of the question, ample no | tice in such an event will, no doubt, b given.
Mr. Redmond : Will the right hon. gen tleman bear in mind that the opposition t a vote of this kind will not be confined t hon. members on this side of the House
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman : We do no know what opposition there may be unti the time comes.

Mr. Redmond : Can the right hon, gen | tleman refer me to the precedents which h says there are ? . Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman : I. can giv one important precedent, which is reall analogous in every respect. I will commu nicate with the hon. member the date an circumstances. · DEFENOE OF NATIONAL PRISONERS

Mr. McNeill has asked Sir E. Grey whe ther he is aware that members of the Ba practising before the Native Courts in Egyr are compelled to defend prisoners gratuit ously, and whether, upon failure to appear fo | the defence after selection by the Court, fine of £50 may be inflicted upon them.

Sir Edward Grey has replied that he is no aware of the system which obtains in regar to the point; but he does not see that h can advantageously interfere in a matte which concerns the Egyptian Government.
ALEXANDRIA'S NEW THEATRE.
YESTERDAY'S INAUGURATION.

The inaug ration of the New Alhambra theatre, which took place last night, was an immense success, and both the management of the theatre and the Lombardo troupe, to whom the inauguration was entrusted, must be greatly pleased with the evening's results. We can only bestow unstinted praise upon Mr. Conegliano, who has provided Alexandria with a theatre constructed on modern lines, and equipped with all the accessories to which one is accustomed in the theatrical centres of Europe. The seating capacity of the theatre is 1,500, and every precaution has been taken for the safe exit of a crowded house in case of fire. Both sides of the theatre contain half a dozen or more doors, and the only criticism we would pass in this respect is upon the main entrance, the doors of which open inwards instead of outwards. The stage is also provided with a water curtain which, should a fire occur, would be let down immediately and would automatically flood the anditorium. The theatre is also artistically decorated and equipped generally, the floor slopes so that a good view of the stage is obtained from every seat, and the boxes, which number 56 in all, are spacious and airy. | For last night's performance of the “Geisha"

the house was almost filled, at least 1,200 people being present, and the company was heartily applauded at every pause. We refrain from commenting upon the performance as, doubtless owing to it being a "first night" and a strange stage, many faults were to be found, and the company was obviously not at its best. Mr. E Urbano, however, deserves special mention. This year, as last year, he is the life and soul of the company, and has proved himself to be a born actor. The play was admirably staged and every thing went off without a hitch, but great improvement is necessary in the limelight, which sheds a minimum of light on the stage and a maximum of light on the upper boxes and roof of the theatre. The orchestra, under the bâton of Mr. Domenico Lombardo, is exceptionally excellent, but at times drowned the | voices of the singers.
FARID BEY IN PARIS.
A REMARKABLE INTERVIEW

Kamel's aide-de-camp, Farid Bey, who is now in Paris, has been giving his opinions to the "Eclair.” After criticising Lord Cromer's policy and declaring that his successor had been instructed to win over the Egyptians, the Bey said that the best meang to attain such an end would be the pardon of the Denishwai "victims.” But he argued that the national party - would not be content with trilling reforms "more illusory i than useal." Its chief requirements were epmpulsory and free prima ary instruction in Arabios the English for the French language, or both being added to the course, gratuitons education in at least thirty per cent of the secondary schools, and the restoration of the 'Egyptian mission in Europe,” which used to send quite torty, pupils yearly to England, France, and Germany.

Asked for his opinion of the financial crisis, Farid Bey answered that it was only superficial, and that landowners were scarsely affected by it. - It was the shares of the many companies with which the Egyptian market was literally inundated which had suffered. Farid Bey, indeed, calmly declared that the general idea was that the crisis, such as it was, had been caused by the English bankers at Lord Cromer's instigation to prove that this panic had been occasioned by his departure. But the Egyptiar. bankers had combined to resist the downward movement and to 'avert a crash. "The market is beginning to recover, and it is hoped that this crisis will pass off without making any victims," Farid Bey added, concluding with the gratuitous remark that the English Press had been trying to discredit the Egyptians in the estimation of European capihalists.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
Harari Pasha is leaving Alexandria on Saturday for Europe by the Austrian-Lloyd steamer.

Mr. Mansfeldt de Cardonnel Findlay, late of the British Agency, Cairo, the newly-appointed British Minister Resident in Dresden, was last week received in formal audience by the King, to whom he presented his credentials.
Miralai H. Hopkinson bey, Commandant of Alexandria Police, has been granted 2 months and 20 days leave of absence on private affairs dating from the 31st inst.
s e

The following passengers have arrived at Cairo from Khartoum by the express : Captain Birchman, Mr. Bonus, Kaim. Young Bey, Mr. Bevan, Pearson Bey, Bimb, Headlama Mrs. Himens, Mr. W. Zaizal, Bimb. Vaughan, Mr. Vines, Mr. Hatchard, Bimb. FitzGerald.

The marriage will take place at Warden, Northumberland, on the 31st inst. of Mr.F. Bernard Jacomb, Egyptian Irrigation Service, and Miss Mary Ethel Gertrude Cruddas. eldest daughter of the Rev. George Cruddas, of Nether Warden.

A marriage has been arranged and will take place in September between Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Miss Jean Lackie, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leckie, of Blackheath and Crowborough. Sir Conan Doyle's first wife, to whom he was married in 1886, died a year ago, leaving two children.
Dr. N. Kasasis, professor of the University of Athens, and president of the Hellenie Society, has arrived in London, where he | intends to make a stay of about two months'
duration. The object of his mission is to | make the British public acquainted with the real state of affairs in Macedonia.

BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE

(Aujourd'hui à midi). Aujourd'hui le marché a présenté un aspect encore plus défavorable qne les jours précédents. L'affluence des vendeurs, qui ne trouvent que difficilement des contre-parties, a déterminé une nouvelle baisse partielle. Les transactions, commeon le conçoit dans de telles circonstances, sont restées clairsemées.
Les valeurs dirigeantes n'ont pas échappe à la baisse. L'Agricole revient de 7 11/16 à 7 5/8 et la National Bank de 19 5/16 à 1€ 15/16. La Delta Light. est cependant plus ferme à 9 5/16.

Parmi les dépréciations les plus notables i faut signaler une perte de 10 fr. sur les Dividendes Tramways à 290, de 1/4 de livre sur le Comptoir à 2 1/8 l'ancienne action et 2 la nouvelle, de P.T. 10 sur la fondateur Allotment à 50.

En baisse également l'Alexandria Water de 109/16 à 10 1/2, la Bière du Caire de 100 a 95 la Privilégiée et de 38 à 37 la Dividende les Cotton Mills de 3 à 2/6, la Salt and Soda de 16/9 à 16, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 310 à 309 l'ancienne et de 264 à 261 la fouvelle, les Lots Turcs de 166 à 164, la Cassa di Sconto de 32 à 30, la Delta Land de 1 7/16 à 1 5/16, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/6 à 20 vendeurs, l'Investment de 7/16 à 3/8, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/8 à 4 1/16, l'action Allotment de i 15/16 à 1 7/8, la Port-Said Salt de 14/6 à 14, les Cotton Ginners de 1 3/8 à 1 1/4.
La Banque d'Athènes reprend, au contraire, de 113 à 113 1/2, et la Banque d'Orient de 114 à 114 1/2.
Le reste de la cote demeure sans changement

Demain anra lieu la vente aux enchères publiques des titres suivants : 415 Delta Land, 440 Salt and Soda, 30 Delta Light Preference, 10 Delta Light Deferred, 150 New Egyptian, 50 Daïra Sanieh, 125 Investment et 25 Com. pagnie Frigorifique.

Nous apprenons que M. Horschitz, l'un des délégués de la National Bank, prépose à la liquidation de la Cassa di Sconto, a donné sa démission, pour des raisons que l'on ignore. La National Bank a désigné à sa place M. Attilio Alessandrini, qui est très connu dans le monde financier de notre ville M, Alessandrini a dejà en l'occasion de montrer de très sérieuses qualités comme comptable et comme financier. Après avoi débuté au Crédit Lyonnais, M. Alessandrini a contribué à l'établissement à Alexandrie de la succursale du Banco di Roma.

En remplacement des membres démission naires de l'Association des Courtiers en va leurs, M.M. J. Arditi, P. Augustino et D Klat, l'Assemblée a élu hier M. J. Bekhyt par 43 voix, M. J. P. Rodocanachi par 4 voix et M. F. S. Rossano par 36 voix.

NOTES ET CRITIQUBS
Le Caire, Lundi 15 juillet. * Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres est

resté à 3 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé, vendredi passé, de 1/8 à 84 1/4 pour se maintenir à ce prix le lendemain. L'Unifiée est remontée de 1/4 à 101. La National Bank a perdu, vendredi, non moins de 5/8 à 19 1/4 pour regagner 1/8 samedi à 19 3/8. L'Agricole a rétrogradé de 1/8 à 7 3/4. La Daïra Sanieh est demeurée inchangée à 13 1/2. La Delta Light a avancé de 1/8 à 9 5/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a reculé samedi de 4 francs à 680 et la Banque d'Athènes de 2 francs à 115.
Comme d'ordinaire tous les lundis, nous avons en, ce matin, un marché flasque, indécis et tant soit peu lourd, dans l'attente du vent qui soufflera cette semaine de Londres et cie Paris.

Dans le cofipartiment des Banques, la National et l'Agricole, renseignées en recul à Londres, où des ventes à terme importantes auraient été faites vendredi passé pour compte de l'Egypte, ont été ramenées presque sans affaires à 19 3,8 et 7 11/16.
La Daïra Sanieh a été mieux tenue à 13 1/8-3/16. La Béhéra a faibli à 24 3/4. L'Allotment est revenu à 1 7/8 et sa part à 57.

La Delta Light a progressé à 9 3/16-1/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont reculé à 173-174. La Brasserie des Pyramides a fléchi à 86 et sa part à 32. Les Automobiles sont tombées à 1 9/16. Les fondateurs Héliopolis ont avancé à 9 3/4.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Egyptian se sont alourdis à 5 1/16-1/8. Les Upper Egypt ont faibli à 2 3/4 et les Ritz à 0 5/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est tassée à 1 9/16-5/8, les New Egyptian à 13 sh. 3, les Abdy à 07/16 et les Aboukir Land á 31 sh.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 8 Juillet, l'intéressant passage suivant :

“ Il s'est produit en fin de semaine, au Stock Exchange, de bonnes demandes en valeurs égyptiennes, . spécialement en National Bank, qui a atteint 20, et en Agricole, qui se maintient ferme à 8. Ces achats ont été faits en grande partie pour le continent et pour l'Ecosse. On commence, décidément, à se rendre un compte plus exact de l'excellence des conditions économiques générales de la vallée du Nil de l'abondante récolte du coton et du haut prix qu'on en tirera, ce qui ramènera l'or en masse dans le pays. Certes, la crise que les marchés do Caire et d'Alexandrie viennent de traverser aura des effets pendant quelques mois encore, ainsi que sa répercussion sur les autres branches de l'activité sociale. Mais c'est pousser le pessimisme à outrance que de prétendre que la contrée est ruinée pour une lon
gue série d'années

"Une haute personnalité financière d'ici, dont le nom a été souvent cité ces temps derniers à propos des embarras du marché égyptien, a eu l'occasion de déclarer que l'Egypte est appelée, malgré tout, à donner lieu à des surprises encore plus agréables que celles que nous ont déjà values ses vingt premières années de développement et de prospérité.

" La conversation portait sur l'avenir des terrains, ainsi que des Sociétés qui s'en occupent. L'éminent financier dont il est question a bien reconnu que la spéculation avait imprimé, en dernier lieu, à la plus-value un essor imprudemment rapide ; mais il s'est élevé, avec raison, contre l'opinion suivant laquelle le prix du terrain en général serait appelé à suivre à l'avenir une marche décroissante. “ On perd de vue, a-t-il fait remarquer en dernier ressort, que la population de l’Egypte est composée, pour plus de neuf dixièmes, d'in| digènes dont beaucoup s'enrichissent à vue

d'ail et placent leurs disponibilités uniquement en terrains, en terrains de culture aussi bien qu'en terrains de construction. L'avenir des Sociétés foncières et immobilières en Egypte n'est donc pas aussi compromis qu'on se plaît à le prétendre.”
Carnet de l'actionnaire.
Le dividende de 3 shellings par action. moins l'income-tax, de l’Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. est payable à partir d'aujourd'hui aux guichets de la National Bank of Egypt.

Les actionnaires de la Société Egyptienne de la Bourse Commerciale de Minet-el-Bassal sont informés qu’un dividende intérimaire de 3 % (soit 12 shellings par action) est payable à partir d'aujourd'hui à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank contre détachement du coupon No. 36.
Les recettes de la Delta Light Railways Co. pour la semaine au 6 Juillet courant se sont élevées à L.E. 4,516 contre 3,926 en 1906, soit en augmentation de L.E. 590.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1907 se chiffrent par L.E. 64,518 contre 52.954 pour la période correspondante de l'exercice précédent, soit en majoration de L.E. 11,564.

Les recettes des Tramways du Caire pour le mois de Juin dernier, qui clôture l'exercice 1906-07, ont été de Frs. 573,105 contre 451,947.60 pour la période correspondante de 1906, soit en plus-value de Frs. 121,157.13, ou près de 27 0/0.
L'exercice entier se termine ainsi avec un total de Frs. 6,084,663 contre 4,925,977.55 l'an dernier et 4,040,157.13 en 1904-1905.
La progression de 1905-1906 est donc de Frs. 1,158,685.45 on 23 0/0. L'augmentation de 1906-1907 sur 1904-1905 est de Francs 2,044,505.87 ou 50 1/2 pour cent.

Messieurs les abonnés qui par erreur ni devraient pas recevoir de carte d'invitation sont priés de bien vouloir la réclamer au secré tariat du Casino.
Pour les non abonnés le prix sera de P.T. 20

HOSTILE LONDON DEMONSTRATION.

p.hi: LONDON, July 15. A great demonstration was held yesterday in Trafalgar Square to protest against any "entente" with Russia, whose regime was bitterly denounced. Subsequently, the crowd, led by Mr. Thorne, M.P., the Socialist Mr. Hyndman, and others, marched to the Foreign Office. The police dispersed them after half an hour's desperate scrummaging. Several persons were badly bruised, including Mistress Despard.

div.p: COMBINED NAVAL REVIEW.
BERGEN, July 15. Prince Henry of Prussia's squadron is on its way here to meet the British cruiser squadron.
It is believed that the Emperor, who is now n's here yatching, will review the combined fleet.
THE BRITISH FLEET.
MISHAP TO DESTROYER.
LONDON, July 15. The destroyer "Lee” has arrived at Plymouth with her side badly stove in in a collision with the Dutch cruiser "Friesland.” (Reuter)
KAID MACLEAN'S CAPTURE.
STEPS FOR RELEASE.

p.hi: Fez, July 15. 1,000 troops have left to combine with the forces concentrating on the Hkmass country, for the purpose of effecting the release of Sir H. Maclean.

div.p: BOMBS IN STAMBOUL.
AMERICAN EMBASSY IN DANGER.
CONSTANTINOPLE, July 15. A bomb has exploded in front of the American Einbassy. Four young girls were wounded.
KHEDIVE'S BIRTHDAY
EGYPTIAN STUDENTS IN FRANCE.
PARIS, July 15. Egyptian and French students celebrated the anniversary of the Khedive's birthday. Cordial toasts were exchanged. (Havas)
AVENGING A MURDER.
MELBOURNE, July 15. The crniser "Cambrian” has landed a force in the New Hebrides to avenge the murder of a European by natives. A bluejacket has been killed and another, wounded. (Reuter)
MINISTERIAL AMENITIES.

Rome, July 15. Baron Aehrenthal, accompanied by the Austrian Ambassador in Italy, arrived yesterday at Signor Tittoni's residence in Desio (Lambardy). The two Ministers will go on Tuesday to Racconigi where they will lunch with the King and Queen. Signor Tittoni will return Baron Behrenthal's visit at Semmering on 14th August. Both of them will visit the Emperor at Ischl on the following day.(Reuter)
Rome, July 15. Baron Aehrental and Signor Tittoni were in conference for two hours. (Reuter)
5. CROWNED HEADS'CONGRATULATION
Paris, July 15. Several Sovereigns have telegraphed the | congratulations to M. Fallières. The Ambassa sdors signed the visitors' book at the Elysée.

p.hi: NEW YORK, July 15. The newspapers report frequent collision with the Japanese on the coast of California.

div.p: GENERAL BOTHA FIRM.

p.hi: PRETORIA, July 15. The firm reply of General Botha to a miners deputation, refusing to introduce an arbitra tion bill this session and advising them to return to work, is likely to lead to the end o the strike.

div.p: St. John's July 15. The fishery negotiations have practically reached an impasse. Arbitration on the inter pretation of the Anglo-American treaty of 1818 is now being mooted.

THE TYRANNY OF LONDON.

"People who write from London about London for the provinces very frequently speak of 'London opinion,' saying that the 'London opinion' on such-and-such is so-and-so; but they rarely state in what way they get ‘London opinion,'” says the "Edinburgh Evening News,"

"An entertaining and suggestive article on 'The Tyranny of London' is contributed to the "Referee” by Mr. Sydney Brooks, a jonrnalist from America...... He remarks that London is not only the biggest capital in the world, bnt the most comprehensive. 'London,' writes Mr. Brooks, 'not only dominates England, but overpowers it-in a measure devitalises it.' He adds that no other capital, with the doubtfal exception of Paris, absorbs so much of the national life around it. Berlin is not to Germany, Rome is not to Italy, Vienna is not to Austria, still less is Madrid to Spain, all that London is to England-by which, presumably, Mr. Brooks means Great Britain.

"While admitting the extent to which London dominates the rest of the land, Mr. Brooks says that there is one sphere beyond the influence of its absorbent magnetism, the sphere of politics. 'Except,' he writes; ‘at brief moments of intense national excitement, London has never had the same political power as Paris. For one thing, provincial and local life and government are far too highly developed among us to permit of the centralised ascendancy of anyone city. For another, London is altogether too languid, too social, and too sociable to be a keen politician. There is no city in which it is so hard to start a 'movement.' Its political opinions nine times out of ten are the opinions of clubland and the West End,

“No doubt there is much truth in this—and the great political movements of recent years did not have their origin here. At the same time innumerable movements have begun here, as Mr. Brooks may be willing to admit. Take such movements as Æstheticism, Anti-Vaccination, Votes for Women, Bernard-Shawism, Rodinism, Archeritis, the Society of Twelve, and Tubes-all these things had their birth in London, and of some of them London is very proud indeed. ... Mr. Brooks proceeds that the city is at once too big and too much de. pendent on society to have either the concentration or the energy necessary for political leadership, adding that even to its own affairs it is magnificently indifferent. 'It has no civic consciousness' he says, for sense of a corporate life or local pride'. ...

"Mr. Brook expresses wonder as to whether or not it is a good thing for a country to be ruled by so overwhelming a capital as we. possess in London. He wants to know if the domination of a Paris or a London is a real or only a seeming advantage. He asks :

Does a nation fare better or worse when it escapes the toll which such huge agglomerations exact on the social health, the intellectual alertness, and the politicat virility of the people? : . . Washington is a capital by prenatal malice aforethought; it was to be the capital that it was called into existence. And within the last year or two history has repeated itself in the Antipodes with curious carefulness. The same fears and jealousies that moved Americans over a century ago to fix the seat of the Federal Government on a stretch of marshy woodland, far away from the real life of the nation, have all been stirring the Australian democracy; and the rivalries of the States, and especially of the big cities like Melbourne and Sydney, have finally cast the Australian capital of the future into the outer solitudes.

"Having so delivered himself, Mr. Brooks has a statement that will not easily pass muster without range of Bow Bells, which is that the talents of the kingdom are so concentrated on London that England (meaning Britain, no doubt, Mr. Brooks ?) as a whole is left comparatively depleted and stagnant.'”
THE GOVERNOR OF THE LEBANON
The latest issue to hand of the “ Levant Herald” gives the following details about the mew Governor of the Lebanon:

We have much pleasure in announcing that H.E. Youssouf Bey Coussa. “Chef de Cabinet" of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs, has been named Governor of the Lebanon in succession to the late Marshal Muzzafer Pasha. His Excellency has at the same time been promoted to the rank of Vizier which bears with it the title of Pasha.
We understand that his Excellency and Mme Youssouf Pasha will leave for Beirut in the course of next week.

Youssouf Pasha Franco is the son of the late Franco Pasha, who was also at one time Governor of the Lebanon. He was born in Constantinople in 1856 and entered the service of the Imperial Government at the age of 17. He was first attached to the secretariat of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and obtained rapid promotion in that Department. In 1900 he was named “Chef de Cabinet” of the Minister. He acted as secretary to the Ottoman Delegation at the first Peace Conference. | Youssouf Pasha Franco has throughout | his career at the Ministry for Foreign Affairs displayed diplomatic abilities of the highest order, and he is a persona gratissima both in Ottoman official circles and in the Diplo| matic Body. No better choice could have been made for the important office his Excellency is now called upon to fill, and we beg to join in the numerous congratulations he has already received on his new appointment.

p.hi: Youssouf Pasha possesses mapy Ottoman and Foreign Orders and amongst others the Grand : Cordons of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh and the medals of the Imtiaz and the Liakat

EGYPTIAN TEMPLES.
EXHIBITION AT KING'S COLLEGE.

The exhibition of the results of the season's work by the Egypt Exploration Fund, which opened last week at King's College, is one of more than usual interest. It represents the finish of one of the greatest works of archæolo gical exploration ever undertaken by an English society. More than fourteen years ago the fund commenced its work of clearing the great temple on the face of the cliffs at Deir el Bahari, near Thebes. This immense edifice, | built by the great Queen Hatshepsu, was one of the wonders of Egypt, differing in style from all other temples, and, especially from the | temples of Thebes. The work entailed not merely the exploration of the temple, but also, as far as possible, a restoration of the edifice by restoring the fallen or broken pieces to their positions, and the removal of Coptic and other buildings which had been built within the temple.

All visitors to Egypt are familiar with this beautiful edifice, rising as it does terrace above terrace from the plain to the face of the cliff. The festival hall, the curious birth chamber, the corridor with sculptures representing the naval expedition to the incense land of Persil, now called Somaliland, have all been cleared and restored as far as possible. This work occupied about ten years, and was carried out by Professor Neville, assisted by Mr. Howard Carter. The large temple belonged to the eighteenth dynasty, B.C. 1800. In clearing away the apparent rubbish heaps on the south side of the enclosure, an astonishing find was made of a beautiful funeral temple of Mentuhetys, of the eleventh dynasty. Four Seasons have been devoted to the exploration of this beautiful temple, and the work is now complete, having occupied about fourteen years at an average expenditure of about £1,000 a year. It is from this temple that the objects now exhibited come.

THE TOMB OF THE KING. The whole of the edifice was grouped round a central pyramid which marked the tomb of the King. The chief object of this year's work was to find this tomb. After much labour a sloping passage, 600ft. long, was found under the platform, but it was impossible to enter the chamber this way as the huge blocks of sandstone forming the roof had fallen. It was then resolved to dig a side passage into the tomb chamber, and at last entrance was obtained. But tomb robbers had been there before. There are here exhibited many objects of interest-funeral boats, little models of groups of servants, bows, arrows, and staffs of office, which had been in many cases stripped. of their gold plating. One very fine boat with a double line of oars is exhibited. In the centre of the tomb was a great shrine, over 12ft. high and 10ft. wide, constructed of translucent alabaster, but it was too heavy to move.

By far the most attractive portion of this exhibition will be the beautiful painted sculptures in a style peculiar to the period, and probably the work of Mertisen, who was the Court artist and sculptor of that day, The portraits of the King and his queens, especially the Queen Aashait, exhited on Table B, have a delicacy of workmanship that is most astonishing. The coloured hieroglyphics are really miniature works of art. The procession of princesses is a beautiful piece of drawing. Especially t be noticed are the painted scenes

from the Chapel of the Princess Kemsit, pro- bably a negress. This work of art and the mummy of the lady will be fouud later in the British Museum. Students of art should notice the hunting scenes and the fine drawing of birds. There is only one warlike scene, and that appears to represent a war against the people of Sinai.

THE SMALLER EXHIBITS. In the clearing up many sinall objects of great interest were found, such as workmen's tools, hammers, nails, chisels, and paint brushes. The display of the beautiful blue glazed ware, used especially as votive offerings to Hathor, the goddess of the turquoise land, is very fine. The textile work is also good, including painted pieces of linen with figures of a whole family, and especially rare are the pieces of linen with beads interwoven, not sewn on. Mention of some curious pilgrim "ex votos" must be made. These are tracings 1 of men's sandals, with their names scratched l in the middle. If the exhibition is somewhat mixed, it represents the completion of a great work. Next season the fund will undertake Tavtensive work at Abydos. En

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.
